name: Katelyn
comment info: I notice that the high-income countries are clustered in the middle of the axis. I also notice that the lower-income countries are more likely to eat fast food, because the fast food is cheaper. However, if the country is too poor, they won't eat much fast food because fast food restaurants would rather put their restaurants in higher-income countries, where citizens there can afford to purchase their food. I wonder what they constituted as fast food. Would "healthy" fast food restaurants, like Chipotle, are recognized as fast food. I also wonder how they counted each of the fast food restaurants, and how many people eat there.

name: Rania R
comment info: I noticed a strong positive correlation between x and y for the high-income areas, a weak positive correlation for the middle income, and a negative correlation between the x and y for the lower middle-income area's. I noticed the higher income areas are more clustered The fast-food sales increase in the upper and lower income countries as the purchasing of fast food increases so does the wealth. I wonder if the correlation between fast food and wealth increasing has to do with fast food being cheaper than healthy food. I also wonder if the increase in fast food led to an increase in obesity and health problems(diabetes, heart failure. I chose the title wealth over health because the people who eat more fast food have increased wealth. This may indicate people eating unhealthy food just because it is cheaper.

name: Jolie Li
comment info:
Quality and Choices Available 
I first noticed how countries with a larger population (a larger chance of low income) or just a country with lower middle or upper middle income receive more increasing wealth percentages 
 as fast food is cheap. I really wonder what a graph about expensive food sales and percentage of income would be like if compared with this graph. The story this graph is telling is the countries with higher incomes have a population with a better quality of life and so, therefore, they don't have fast foods as an only option.

name: Arron Feller [STUDENT]
comment info: I noticed that there was a strong positive correlation between increasing wealth and increasing fast food sales. In my eyes, increasing wealth is the independent variable. I also noticed that lower to middle income countries generally bought more fast food than that of higher income countries. I wonder if there is a reason behind this correlation, as all I can think of is that lower-income countries need fast food because it is a cheap source of food that can help save money and the fast food corporations are taking advantage of that. If I were to create a headline, it would be Fast Food Destroys the Poor.

name: Steven Dai
comment info: I noticed that there is a positive correlation between the wealth of the country and the increase in fast food sales. I also wonder about the outlier.

name: W. Cameron
comment info: I notice that high income countries are not buying fast food as much as low income countries. I wonder if the culture within these countries impact the fast food market. I see that the countries with lower middle income are more likely to purchase fast food because its cheaper, while upper classes can afford healthier options.

name: Steph Zhang
comment info: I noticed that in general fast food sales increased in most countries from 2000-2005, particularly drastic with counties with lower middle incomes. Most of these highlighted lower middle income countries also had greater increase in wealth although % of change in wealth in either direction does not seem to impact the change of fast food sales. I wonder if the baseline GDP & its larger delta has any correlation with the change of fast food sales.  What might be happening is that as lower middle income countries increase in wealth, people can afford to eat out more, more people having jobs and have less time to cook. Meal preparation are essentially more outsourced to food preparation industry.

name: Richard Comet
comment info: I notice that the higher income countries are decreasing in fast food sales and the low income and middle income are increasing. I think the higher income countries aren't focusing so much on fast foods and they focus on other things that will increase their sales. The lower and upper income countries focus more on fast food instead of better things that will gain them money and they spend way to much in fast food. The lower income countries are not charging enough and their not getting their money back.

name: Emily Comet
comment info: What I notice in this graph is that high income countries are decreasing in fast food sales. I also notice the lower and upper middle income countries are increasing in fast food sales. I wonder if the countries with decreasing wealth has a higher population, because the more people in the country the more likely the country is to become poor. A good headline for this graph would be  " Fast food sales and wealth." My claim is that increasing and decreasing fast food sales, determine the wealth of the countries. The evidence for my claim is the graph.

name: Brinna Comet
comment info: Economic stagnation yields a less favorable market for fast food. I notice that the wealthiest nations are among the most middling data points, implying that as countries reach the highest wealth echelon, their economic growth slows. This slowed growth yields stability, allowing a booming middle class that then allows individuals access to more expensive (and often healthier) food options. The poorest nations are usually those with the highest economic growth. Like population, as a nation moves from low to high, initial growth is rapid. During this transitional phase, the lower class is, for the first time, gaining access to greater diversity of food options, maybe even having the option to purchase food rather than grow it for the first time. Additionally, these nations often have massive metropolitan centers rife with poverty, a market environment perfect for the fast food sector to corner.

name: Jakob Comet
comment info: This is obviously a graph showing the trend of fast food consumption threw all the classes. some are up some are down. it seems to be that lower and upper middles class eat more fast food then high income.

I wonder if it has to do with prices, or certain locations in the countries. The graph might be telling us how fast food affects different income families, and how much of a contribution fast food makes in the economy.

name: frank comet
comment info: This is a very interesting graph showing multiple countries around the world and whether they are increasing or decreasing in wealth and fast food sales. It seems like that most of the higher income countries are on the trend of decreasing fast food sales as well as decreasing wealth. I think that this headline should be Changes in Fast Food Sales Depending on a Country's Wealth. I also wonder what year this survey was taken in? Its very interesting.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Not only are fast-food sales increasing in the United Sates, but also eating fast food is a life-style change that is being exported to countries around the world.  With more fast-food sales and more wealth, there are some unintended consequences that you may not have thought about until now.  View the Reveal tomorrow afternoon and see where the article took this data in explaining what is happening to new customers.
Jesse of Brooklyn had an interesting headline “Fast Food Preys on the Poor.” Discuss with your class whether there is evidence of this in the graph or do you have other knowledge that supports this headline.
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into what the graph shows. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, October 18 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and three Stat Nuggets. 

Next week’s graph will be released TOMORROW – THURSDAY OCTOBER 18! You may respond before the live moderation on Wednesday, October 24, during the moderation, or after the moderation by going to the archives for the graph.  No surprise – the graph has to do with the upcoming midterm elections and the barriers to voting by state.   Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston and Jared Derksen in Rancho Cucamonga, California. 

NOTE:  There will be no “What’s Going On In This Graph?” on Wednesday, October 31.  Happy Halloween.

name: A.McNutt
comment info: There is a correlation between increasing fast food sales and wealth in countries. Also many high end countries didn't have as much fast food sales as the lower end countries, if any the fast food sales were decreasing.  The higher upper middle countries see a negative impact of fast food sales. It is likely the low cost might attract lower class countries.

name: Gordon Robertson
comment info: Economic stagnation yields a less favorable market for fast food. I notice that the wealthiest nations are among the most middling data points, implying that as countries reach the highest wealth echelon, their economic growth slows. This slowed growth yields stability, allowing a booming middle class that then allows individuals access to more expensive (and often healthier) food options. The poorest nations are usually those with the highest economic growth. Like population, as a nation moves from low to high, initial growth is rapid. During this transitional phase, the lower class is, for the first time, gaining access to greater diversity of food options, maybe even having the option to purchase food rather than grow it for the first time. Additionally, these nations often have massive metropolitan centers rife with poverty, a market environment perfect for the fast food sector to corner.

replies.comment info: @Gordon Robertson, very concise summary of economic growth and how it affects purchasing choices.  With these insights, now look at the graph.  What do you notice?  Do all of these countries follow your thoughts about economic growth?  The article that this graph came from is about the consequences of economic growth.  Would you share with us a headline?  Then, tomorrow afternoon, make sure you go to the Reveal, which will be at the bottom of the graph’s release.  See what the journalist found in a developing country.

name: Angelina
comment info: Based on the graph, there seems to be a slight positive correlation between wealth and fast food sales. It is also evident that fast food chains are targeting lower to middle income countries. These chains may be targeting these countries because of the cheaper food options they provide, making these dining options affordable.

replies.comment info: HI, @Angelina.  You are onto something here.  Lower income customers can afford fast food.  What are some of the consequences of eating more fast food?  Would you share with us a catchy headline that captures the main idea of this graph?  Make sure you go to tomorrow’s Reveal that appears at the bottom of this feature.  There you’ll read about association and correlation and how they are different.

name: yEeEt
comment info: The graph shows a correlation between middle income and increased fast food sales, which implies there is higher consumption of unhealthy food by the middle class. For example, Vietnam, a lower middle income country has the second highest amount of fast food sales. This could be explained because average middle class people cannot afford to frequently buy organic, non-GMO, unprocessed food.

name: Jesse Duval
comment info:
I notice that the Lower-Income countries have a greater increase in Fast food sales as opposed to the High-Income countries.
I wonder if this has to do with the fact that fast food is cheap, which I assume would cause people of lower-income to buy more food more frequently.
A catchy headline could be "Fast Food Preys on the Poor".

replies.comment info: Hi, @Jesse Duval.  You’ve hit on something.  Your catchy headline is “Fast Food Preys on the Poor.”  What do you mean by this?  Do you see evidence in the graph or is your thinking based on what you know about fast food and the poor?  Please explain.  Then, tomorrow afternoon, go back to the graph and see the Reveal at the bottom of the entry.   The Reveal gives you the link to the New York Times article and more.  Read what the journalist found when then went to Ghana.

name: Mrs. Nataro's Students
comment info:
Here are our thoughts:
1) There appears to be a correlation between increasing fast food sales and increasing wealth, meaning more money was related to more food sales.   However, we thought there would be more blue dots (high income) in the lower corner, because we thought people with higher incomes would be buying more expensive dining options.  

2) We additionally thought that countries that are wealthier might also be developing more which would lead to more fast food restaurants.  In countries where there were already many fast food restaurants, there wouldn't be as a dramatic increase in fast food sales. For example, the United States would fall in this category.  For a country like China, they probabably had a much larger increase in reataurants as certain places become more Westernized.

replies.comment info:
Thank you @Mrs. Nataro’s Students for your observations and reflections.

You say, “We thought there would be more blue dots (high income) in the lower corner, because we thought people with higher incomes would be buying more expensive dining options. Would you please explain more about your reasoning?  You may have something very significant here.

How about a few snappy headlines that capture the graph’s main ideas?

name: Emerald Henry
comment info: Could Fast Food Chains be targeting low income countries? What I noticed was that the Lower middle and Upper middle income countries are higher in fast food sales and the High Income countries are decreasing and are a bit more scattered/clustered in one area of the graph. Thinking to myself I wonder if the reasoning behind the increase of fast food sales for lower and upper middle income countries is that the chain of fast food restaurants are targeting those countries to gain more profit and attract those who have less in their pockets only being able to afford fast foods. I believe what is happening in this graph is the clear sign that Fast food chains are more common and grown in sales for lower income areas and countries because fast food is more affordable, and can be accessed better than a healthy market. Fast food can be cheap to buy, and easy to attain. Because of this simple process and the amount of fast food chains in their areas it is an easier and effective way for low income people to have food for themselves or family's. As for the countries increasing in wealth it could also be due to those countries bringing in those restaurants for people to attain food. Fast food is becoming an epidemic around the world not just the U.S, we should all be seeing its effects and take action.

name: Moderator Jared
comment info: This graph has a positive trend. That is, very roughly, the graph is trending upwards from the lower left to the upper right. I wonder what this tells us?

name: SDCI PIVOT
comment info: Wow! There was so much to notice and wonder with this graph! Once we understood what the scale and the colour-coding was telling us, we started to ask questions about individual countries which would really require more research to answer. For example we first noticed that Greece had decreased in fast food sales by about 25% even though they had high income status. Why the decrease? This prompted another student to ask about Morocco as it is low/middle income but with stable wealth and an average increase (25%) in Fast Food Sales. Once this student commented, we had an "ah ha" moment as we realized that the horizontal axis had a lot of information to offer us. We went back to Greece which we then realized had significantly  decreasing wealth. We wondered why this is and thought that this would require more understanding of the economic and political situation in the individual countries.  Students cued into Argentina which had an astounding 120% plus increase in Fast Food Sales. They wondered if the explosion  had to do with soccer or tourism or some other major political/economic change. We then zoned in on  the United States. We asked why the US had only average increase in Fast Food sales and average increase in wealth. We then realized that the reference point was 2010-2015 which meant that the US already had an amazing amount of Fast Food sales at that point already. One of our students felt that a catchy title might be "US Falling Behind in Fast Food Sales Growth"

replies.comment info: @SDCI PIVOT So many great observations here. Interesting data sets often leave us wondering about other variables that are NOT on the graph, but that we're curious to hear more about.

name: Bill
comment info: The poorer countries are darker colors

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Bill
Notice the labels on the x-axis.  That adds some more information about the countries.  What do you now notice and what can you  conclude?

Are some countries, like Brazil, places where it is cheaper to eat fast food than to cook? Also, why are so many high income countries experiencing loss of wealth? What else is affecting wealth and fast food sales?

replies.comment info:
@Mrs. Lang
Did your class notice the direction of the plot (in general)? That doesn't answer the "why?" that your class is wondering about, but it does give us some information about the relationship.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Teachers told us that they wanted to see the graphs sooner so there is more time to lesson plan.  Here is the revised schedule for “What’s Going On In This Graph?”.   

Thursday afternoons:  Release the graph for the following week.

Wednesday 9 am – 2 pm ET:  Live moderation

Thursday afternoon:  Reveal the article, additional questions, and the Stat Nuggets

Write to us with other suggestions to improve “What’s Going On In This Graph?”.  

Tomorrow afternoon, check out next week’s release – maybe about voting???, as well as The Reveal for today’s graph.

Please note that there will be no “What’s Going On In This Graph?” on Wednesday, October 31.

name: Ellen
comment info: I wonder what qualifies as fast food. There are many newer places where food is pretty fast (such as Chipotle, Panera, B.Good), but they are not the traditional fast food like McDonalds.

replies.comment info: @Ellen: Great question! I also wonder if traditional fast food choices are becoming more healthy? For example, offering carrots instead of fries?

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?” and the Wednesday moderation.  Today’s graph focuses on the change in fast-food sales and wealth by country around the world.  Think about how fast food affects customers.  Study the graph and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.) 

	What do you NOTICE in this graph? 

	What do you WONDER? What are you curious about?

	What’s GOING ON in this graph?
Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.

Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

comment info: This is a very interesting graph showing multiple countries around the world and whether they are increasing or decreasing in wealth and fast food sales. It seems like that most of the higher income countries are on the trend of decreasing fast food sales as well as decreasing wealth. I think that this headline should be Changes in Fast Food Sales Depending on a Country's Wealth. I also wonder what year this survey was taken in? Its very interesting.

name: Tricia
comment info:
Our 7th grade class thinks the headline should be,  Fast Food Sales Vs. Wealth

replies.comment info:
Thank you, @Tricia  Tricia's 7th graders.

You wrote that "lower-income people eat more fast food."  Would you please share with us the evidence in the graph?  What do you notice that lead you to this conclusion?  

You may want to take another look at the axes labels and scales on the graph.  This could lead you to revise your conclusion.
